carousel_items: Long-acting opioid for moderate to severe pain.
May not be the best choice for people who have never taken opioids, or who've only taken shorter-acting opioids for pain.
May be part of a complete program to reduce opioid dependence.
For short-term treatment of opioid dependence, the target dose is 40mg for 2-3 days, then reduced every 2 days.
For long-term drug detoxification treatment the dose is increased until withdrawal symptoms stay away for 24 hours.
Dosing can vary widely, but for most people the general range is 80-120mg daily.
Take exactly as your doctor instructs and don’t take more than you're prescribed.
Can make you dizzy or drowsy.
Avoid activities that need you to be fully alert until you know how it affects you.
Don't mix with alcohol or other sedating drugs.
Constipation is common and may not go away while you're taking this medicine. Drinking lots of water and taking laxatives can help.
Talk to your doctor if it doesn't help enough for your pain.
If you need to stop taking this medicine, work with your doctor to slowly lower your dose. It'll help you avoid withdrawal symptoms.
Careful reduction from your maintenance dose is important. It shouldn't be more than 10% of the total daily dose, reduced every 10 to 14 days.

basics.benefits_moa: Methadone is an opioid medicine (similar to morphine) that works in the brain to lower pain perception. Because withdrawal from Methadone is slower, takes longer, and is less severe than other opioids, it's used under the care of a doctor to treat opioid addiction.
basics.bottom_line: Methadone works well for moderate to severe pain especially nerve-related and complex pain and is effective for maintenance opioid addiction treatment. You need to be careful with dosing.
downsides: Need to use it “around-the-clock for pain control not “as needed”.
Even one dose is too much for child or pet and is a medical emergency so store out of their reach.
Can cause slowed breathing, coma and death from overdose, especially if you mix with other nervous system depressants.
Has a higher risk of affecting heart rate control especially if you have cardiovascular disease (previous heart attack, stroke, fast/uncontrolled heart rate, or irregular heart beat).
Can reduce your ability to focus, think, and react so avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medicine affects you.
Not safe to take if you're pregnant or breast-feeding and can increase the risk of neonatal withdrawal syndrome in women with a history of long-term opioid use.

May cause you to become tolerant (more medicine is needed to treat the same pain) and physically dependent if you’ve used it for a while so don’t stop talking it suddenly or you may feel withdrawal symptoms.
Can cause your blood pressure drop suddenly if you change positions quickly.
Certain prescription and over-the-counter medicines can change the amount of medicine in your body and cause either overdose or withdrawal.

downsides_processed.orig: Need to use it “around-the-clock for pain control not “as needed”.
Even one dose is too much for child or pet and is a medical emergency so store out of their reach.
Can cause slowed breathing, coma and death from overdose, especially if you mix with other nervous system depressants.
Has a higher risk of affecting heart rate control especially if you have cardiovascular disease (previous heart attack, stroke, fast/uncontrolled heart rate, or irregular heart beat).
Can reduce your ability to focus, think, and react so avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medicine affects you.
Not safe to take if you're pregnant or breast-feeding and can increase the risk of neonatal withdrawal syndrome in women with a history of long-term opioid use.

May cause you to become tolerant (more medicine is needed to treat the same pain) and physically dependent if you’ve used it for a while so don’t stop talking it suddenly or you may feel withdrawal symptoms.
Can cause your blood pressure drop suddenly if you change positions quickly.
Certain prescription and over-the-counter medicines can change the amount of medicine in your body and cause either overdose or withdrawal.

upsides: Relieves pain and treats opioid addiction.
Good option for people who don't get pain relief with more-common opioids, have side effects or allergies with other options, or have nerve pain (neuropathic pain).
Even low doses are more effective than placebo at treating shooting, burning pain.
Less constipating than other opioid medicines to treat pain.

upsides_processed.orig: Relieves pain and treats opioid addiction.
Good option for people who don't get pain relief with more-common opioids, have side effects or allergies with other options, or have nerve pain (neuropathic pain).
Even low doses are more effective than placebo at treating shooting, burning pain.
Less constipating than other opioid medicines to treat pain.

drugs.one_liner: Treats severe pain and drug dependence.

userStories.tip: Was given this for Fibromyalgia for 6 years. WORKED INCREDIBLY. Never had to increase and could skip. Knocked depression dead in it's tracks. Had to go off after moving to another backwards state in the US.

userStories.indication: Nerve pain due to back sergury
userStories.tip: Was started on 40mg per day, in my case I cut back until I felt some pain then adjusted to relieve pain at 15mg per day. All is good, I can work, and enjoy some type of life. I have been taking for 4 years never had to increase dose.
userStories.identifier: Can't walk, run, stand or sit 24/7 pain
Chronic pain caused by post DVT syndrome
userStories.tip: Better than other opiates for me but there is stigma from people who think it's for drug addicts. Must be taken regularly (2x/day) because it takes a while to build up in body. No use breakthrough pain.

drugs.name: Methadone

carousel_items_processed.orig: Long-acting opioid for moderate to severe pain.
May not be the best choice for people who have never taken opioids, or who've only taken shorter-acting opioids for pain.
May be part of a complete program to reduce opioid dependence.
For short-term treatment of opioid dependence, the target dose is 40mg for 2-3 days, then reduced every 2 days.
For long-term drug detoxification treatment the dose is increased until withdrawal symptoms stay away for 24 hours.
Dosing can vary widely, but for most people the general range is 80-120mg daily.
Take exactly as your doctor instructs and don’t take more than you're prescribed.
Can make you dizzy or drowsy.
Avoid activities that need you to be fully alert until you know how it affects you.
Don't mix with alcohol or other sedating drugs.
Constipation is common and may not go away while you're taking this medicine. Drinking lots of water and taking laxatives can help.
Talk to your doctor if it doesn't help enough for your pain.
If you need to stop taking this medicine, work with your doctor to slowly lower your dose. It'll help you avoid withdrawal symptoms.
Careful reduction from your maintenance dose is important. It shouldn't be more than 10% of the total daily dose, reduced every 10 to 14 days.

risks_warnings.title: Death from lack of oxygen to the body (respiratory depression)
risks_warnings.description: Taking too much Methadone can cause irregular or slow breathing that can put you in a coma and can cause death. Serious breathing effects can happen after pain relief but may last longer. If your lips and fingers start turning blue from low oxygen, see a doctor immediately. In the hospital, doctors can give you a medicine that reverses the effects of Methadone. Don't take more than your doctor prescribes.
risk_factors: People with not enough thyroid hormones

description_processed.orig: Taking too much Methadone can cause irregular or slow breathing that can put you in a coma and can cause death. Serious breathing effects can happen after pain relief but may last longer. If your lips and fingers start turning blue from low oxygen, see a doctor immediately. In the hospital, doctors can give you a medicine that reverses the effects of Methadone. Don't take more than your doctor prescribes.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems (arrhythmias)
risks_warnings.description: Methadone has a higher risk of affecting heart rate control. If you have a history of cardiovascular disease (including previous heart attack, stroke, fast/uncontrolled heart rate, or irregular heartbeat), talk to your doctor before use. Seek medical attention immediately if you feel faint and have palpitations.

description_processed.orig: Methadone has a higher risk of affecting heart rate control. If you have a history of cardiovascular disease (including previous heart attack, stroke, fast/uncontrolled heart rate, or irregular heartbeat), talk to your doctor before use. Seek medical attention immediately if you feel faint and have palpitations.

risks_warnings.title: Driving impairment
risks_warnings.description: Methadone lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medicine affects you.
risk_factors: Taking other medicines that make you less alert

description_processed.orig: Methadone lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medicine affects you.

risks_warnings.title: Drug interactions
risks_warnings.description: Some medicines can affect enzymes that break down Methadone. Certain drugs to treat infections, HIV, and seizures can change the amount of Methadone in the body and cause either overdose or withdrawal. Tell your doctor about any prescription or over-the-counter medications you are taking.
risk_factors: Taking drugs that slow or stop breakdown the breakdown of Methadone

description_processed.orig: Some medicines can affect enzymes that break down Methadone. Certain drugs to treat infections, HIV, and seizures can change the amount of Methadone in the body and cause either overdose or withdrawal. Tell your doctor about any prescription or over-the-counter medications you are taking.

risks_warnings.title: Low blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Methadone can cause severe low blood pressure, fainting, and a drop blood pressure when you change positions, called orthostatic hypotension. You may be more sensitive if you're already taking medicine to lower your blood pressure so be careful. It's important that you tell your doctor about these symptoms before changing your dose or stopping your medication suddenly.
risk_factors: Taking drugs that lower blood pressure

description_processed.orig: Methadone can cause severe low blood pressure, fainting, and a drop blood pressure when you change positions, called orthostatic hypotension. You may be more sensitive if you're already taking medicine to lower your blood pressure so be careful. It's important that you tell your doctor about these symptoms before changing your dose or stopping your medication suddenly.

risks_warnings.title: Neonatal withdrawal syndrome
risks_warnings.description: Methadone passes into breast milk. Women with a history of long-term opioid use increase the risk of neonatal withdrawal syndrome. Symptoms include irritability, vomiting, diarrhea, tremor and lack of weight gain. Opioid withdrawal in infants is a life-threatening emergency and needs medical help right away.
risk_factors: Long-term use of opioids in mother

description_processed.orig: Methadone passes into breast milk. Women with a history of long-term opioid use increase the risk of neonatal withdrawal syndrome. Symptoms include irritability, vomiting, diarrhea, tremor and lack of weight gain. Opioid withdrawal in infants is a life-threatening emergency and needs medical help right away.

risks_warnings.title: Death from overdose
risks_warnings.description: Even 1 dose of Methadone can be too much for a child so store out of reach from children. In adults, raising the dose too quickly, high doses or mixing with alcohol or drugs that interact causes overdose and death. If you suspect a child has taken Methadone, or an adult has taken too much, watch them for decreased activity, extreme tiredness small pupils, and lips and fingers turning blue from low oxygen. Call 911 or go to a hospital immediately. Doctors can give a medicine that reverses the effects of Methadone until the effects wear off.
risk_factors: Mixing with alcohol or drugs that interact with Methadone

description_processed.orig: Even 1 dose of Methadone can be too much for a child so store out of reach from children. In adults, raising the dose too quickly, high doses or mixing with alcohol or drugs that interact causes overdose and death. If you suspect a child has taken Methadone, or an adult has taken too much, watch them for decreased activity, extreme tiredness small pupils, and lips and fingers turning blue from low oxygen. Call 911 or go to a hospital immediately. Doctors can give a medicine that reverses the effects of Methadone until the effects wear off.

risks_warnings.title: Abuse, tolerance, and addiction
risks_warnings.description: Long-acting opioids like Methadone have a greater risk of addiction, abuse, misuse, overdose, and death. Your body can develop tolerance to Methadone, which means that more medicine is needed to treat the same pain. You can become physically dependent on Methadone if you have been using it continuously for more than 1-2 weeks, meaning you'll feel withdrawal symptoms if you stop taking it. You can avoid withdrawal by weaning off of the medication very slowly and taking the exact dose your doctor prescribed. People taking Methadone for pain with a history of drug abuse should ask their doctor about other medicine choices.
risk_factors: Taking more than the prescribed dose
History of drug abuse or mental illness.

description_processed.orig: Long-acting opioids like Methadone have a greater risk of addiction, abuse, misuse, overdose, and death. Your body can develop tolerance to Methadone, which means that more medicine is needed to treat the same pain. You can become physically dependent on Methadone if you have been using it continuously for more than 1-2 weeks, meaning you'll feel withdrawal symptoms if you stop taking it. You can avoid withdrawal by weaning off of the medication very slowly and taking the exact dose your doctor prescribed. People taking Methadone for pain with a history of drug abuse should ask their doctor about other medicine choices.

carousel_items: Before starting Naltrexone, you should be off all opioid medications (including buprenorphine and methadone) for at least 7 to 10 days, otherwise you'll get withdrawal symptoms.
You'll need to use non-opioid pain medications (if necessary) while on Naltrexone.
Wear a medical alert identification if you're taking Naltrexone since you would need to be given non-opioid medications in case of an emergency.
If you're taking Naltrexone for alcohol dependence, it'll make you not want to drink alcohol, but it won't stop the effects of alcohol if you do drink.
Naltrexone can make you feel dizzy the first few times you take it, so avoid doing anything requiring concentration until you know how your body reacts to it.

basics.benefits_moa: Naltrexone blocks all opioid receptors in your body and prevents you from feeling the effects of opioid medications and alcohol.
basics.bottom_line: Naltrexone is good for treating opioid and alcohol dependence. It needs to be used as directed and can't be used with alcohol or opioid pain medications.
downsides: People who try to take opioids after taking Naltrexone are at risk for opioid overdose and death since it takes a large amount of opioids to overcome the effects of Naltrexone.
You won't be able to use any medications with opioids for pain relief since Naltrexone prevents them from working.
The shot is only available as brand name only, so it can be expensive.
Not a good choice if you have liver problems, depression, or are pregnant or breastfeeding.

downsides_processed.orig: People who try to take opioids after taking Naltrexone are at risk for opioid overdose and death since it takes a large amount of opioids to overcome the effects of Naltrexone.
You won't be able to use any medications with opioids for pain relief since Naltrexone prevents them from working.
The shot is only available as brand name only, so it can be expensive.
Not a good choice if you have liver problems, depression, or are pregnant or breastfeeding.

upsides: Available in two different forms: a tablet you take every day and as a shot your doctor gives you once a month.
Good for people who have a mild opioid use disorder and who are highly motivated, or who can be supervised as they take their medication.
Can be used with behavior modification therapy to treat opioid or alcohol use disorders.
Higher success rates are seen in people who use this under supervision.
The tablet is available as a generic.

upsides_processed.orig: Available in two different forms: a tablet you take every day and as a shot your doctor gives you once a month.
Good for people who have a mild opioid use disorder and who are highly motivated, or who can be supervised as they take their medication.
Can be used with behavior modification therapy to treat opioid or alcohol use disorders.
Higher success rates are seen in people who use this under supervision.
The tablet is available as a generic.

drugs.one_liner: Treats alcohol dependence and prevents relapse of addiction to opioids.
drugs.name: naltrexone

carousel_items_processed.orig: Before starting Naltrexone, you should be off all opioid medications (including buprenorphine and methadone) for at least 7 to 10 days, otherwise you'll get withdrawal symptoms.
You'll need to use non-opioid pain medications (if necessary) while on Naltrexone.
Wear a medical alert identification if you're taking Naltrexone since you would need to be given non-opioid medications in case of an emergency.
If you're taking Naltrexone for alcohol dependence, it'll make you not want to drink alcohol, but it won't stop the effects of alcohol if you do drink.
Naltrexone can make you feel dizzy the first few times you take it, so avoid doing anything requiring concentration until you know how your body reacts to it.

risks_warnings.title: Opioid overdose
risks_warnings.description: After opioid detoxification, people are likely to have a reduced tolerance to opioids. If people who have been treated with Naltrexone need to use opioid pain medications in the future, they'll need lower doses of opioids than they used before they started taking Naltrexone. If you give them the opioid dose they used to get, it could result in a potentially life-threatening overdose. People should be alerted that they'll be more sensitive to opioids in the future.

description_processed.orig: After opioid detoxification, people are likely to have a reduced tolerance to opioids. If people who have been treated with Naltrexone need to use opioid pain medications in the future, they'll need lower doses of opioids than they used before they started taking Naltrexone. If you give them the opioid dose they used to get, it could result in a potentially life-threatening overdose. People should be alerted that they'll be more sensitive to opioids in the future.

risks_warnings.title: Opioid withdrawal
risks_warnings.description: Withdrawal symptoms requiring hospitalization can be caused by giving Naltrexone to a person currently dependent on opioid medications. Symptoms of withdrawal can appear within 5 minutes of giving Naltrexone and can last up to 48 hours. Watch for sudden changes including confusion, exhaustion, visual hallucinations, or vomiting and diarrhea that'll require IV fluids given at a hospital.

description_processed.orig: Withdrawal symptoms requiring hospitalization can be caused by giving Naltrexone to a person currently dependent on opioid medications. Symptoms of withdrawal can appear within 5 minutes of giving Naltrexone and can last up to 48 hours. Watch for sudden changes including confusion, exhaustion, visual hallucinations, or vomiting and diarrhea that'll require IV fluids given at a hospital.

risks_warnings.title: Risk to unborn babies
risks_warnings.description: Naltrexone can cause birth defects. Don't use Naltrexone while pregnant. If you're considering having a baby, talk to your doctor about alternative medications.

description_processed.orig: Naltrexone can cause birth defects. Don't use Naltrexone while pregnant. If you're considering having a baby, talk to your doctor about alternative medications.

risks_warnings.title: Liver injury
risks_warnings.description: People taking this medication have suffered sudden liver damage (acute hepatitis), so it's important to have liver function blood work done anytime your doctor feels you may have liver injury. Watch out for becoming overly tired, losing an unusual amount of weight, having severe pain on the right side of your abdomen, or having dark urine. Be sure to talk to a doctor if this occurs.

description_processed.orig: People taking this medication have suffered sudden liver damage (acute hepatitis), so it's important to have liver function blood work done anytime your doctor feels you may have liver injury. Watch out for becoming overly tired, losing an unusual amount of weight, having severe pain on the right side of your abdomen, or having dark urine. Be sure to talk to a doctor if this occurs.

points.name: Insomnia
points.hlt: disturbances in initiating and maintaining sleep

carousel_items: A doctor should supervise your use of this medication as part of a complete treatment program.
Can make you drowsy and dizzy.
Avoid activities that need you to be fully alert until you know how it affects you.
Suboxone film and Zubsolv tablets have different dosing. Be careful.
Don't mix with alcohol or other sedating drugs.
Drink water before putting the film under your tongue.
Don't cut, chew or swallow the film.
If you need to stop taking it, work with your doctor to slowly lower your dose. It'll help you avoid withdrawal symptoms.

basics.benefits_moa: Suboxone is a combination medicine with two parts that work together to treat opioid dependence. Buprenorphine is an opioid pain reliever (similar to morphine). Naloxone mildly counteracts the pain reliever, so it's added to prevent overuse or abuse of this medication.
basics.bottom_line: Suboxone works well to reduce cravings and treat opioid dependence. It's most effective if you have an addiction to heroin or short-acting-opioids.
downsides: Not as good for people who are dependent on long-acting opioids or Methadone because of the risk of a long withdrawal.
Like all opioids, it can cause slowed breathing, coma, and death from overdose, especially if you mix with other nervous system depressants like pain medicine or alcohol.
You have to be very careful with your dose. Changing the size or strength of a film can affect the amount of drug absorbed into your body, and could cause under- or over-dosing.
The film can cause reduced sensation in your mouth, painful burning tongue, or burning mouth syndrome.

downsides_processed.orig: Not as good for people who are dependent on long-acting opioids or Methadone because of the risk of a long withdrawal.
Like all opioids, it can cause slowed breathing, coma, and death from overdose, especially if you mix with other nervous system depressants like pain medicine or alcohol.
You have to be very careful with your dose. Changing the size or strength of a film can affect the amount of drug absorbed into your body, and could cause under- or over-dosing.
The film can cause reduced sensation in your mouth, painful burning tongue, or burning mouth syndrome.

upsides: Effective at preventing abuse or misuse in people who are addicted to opioids. Works best for people addicted to short-acting opioids or heroin.
Your doctor can adjust the dose to a level that controls withdrawal symptoms until you're stable. Studies show the right dose depends on the person and how the drug works for them.
Fewer side effects and drug interactions compared to other similar medicines.

upsides_processed.orig: Effective at preventing abuse or misuse in people who are addicted to opioids. Works best for people addicted to short-acting opioids or heroin.
Your doctor can adjust the dose to a level that controls withdrawal symptoms until you're stable. Studies show the right dose depends on the person and how the drug works for them.
Fewer side effects and drug interactions compared to other similar medicines.

userStories.identifier: Mom w depression & anxiety, in recovery
userStories.tip: Work with your Dr to find the right dose for you. Be aware of when you need your refills, you don't want to run out! I feel this medication saved my life as it allowed me to quit a nasty heroin addiction.
Other than Methadone, best medication without increasing and tolerance for my Chronic Pain EVER!!!
I take 32 milligrams in the morning, same time every morning.

Start with a very low dose and slowly titrate up.  A little goes a long way for pain relief.  I was on 10-12 Norcos a day, but 1 mg of this works perfectly for me.  I split the dosage, and take 1/2 in the AM and 1/2 at lunchtime.
Make sure you take it at the same time everyday, or split it evenly every 12 hours.

drugs.name: Suboxone

carousel_items_processed.orig: A doctor should supervise your use of this medication as part of a complete treatment program.
Can make you drowsy and dizzy.
Avoid activities that need you to be fully alert until you know how it affects you.
Suboxone film and Zubsolv tablets have different dosing. Be careful.
Don't mix with alcohol or other sedating drugs.
Drink water before putting the film under your tongue.
Don't cut, chew or swallow the film.
If you need to stop taking it, work with your doctor to slowly lower your dose. It'll help you avoid withdrawal symptoms.

risks_warnings.title: Low blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Suboxone can cause severe low blood pressure, fainting, and a drop blood pressure when you change positions, called orthostatic hypotension. You might be more sensitive if you're already taking medicine to lower your blood pressure so be careful. It's important that you tell your doctor about these symptoms before changing your dose or stopping your medication suddenly.
risk_factors: taking drugs that lower blood pressure

description_processed.orig: Suboxone can cause severe low blood pressure, fainting, and a drop blood pressure when you change positions, called orthostatic hypotension. You might be more sensitive if you're already taking medicine to lower your blood pressure so be careful. It's important that you tell your doctor about these symptoms before changing your dose or stopping your medication suddenly.

risks_warnings.title: Burning mouth syndrome (BMS)
risks_warnings.description: Suboxone film can cause reduced sense of feeling in the mouth, painful burning tongue, and burning mouth syndrome (BMS). Tell your doctor if you notice excessive redness in your mouth after using the film. You may need to change the dose form.

description_processed.orig: Suboxone film can cause reduced sense of feeling in the mouth, painful burning tongue, and burning mouth syndrome (BMS). Tell your doctor if you notice excessive redness in your mouth after using the film. You may need to change the dose form.

risks_warnings.title: Liver failure
risks_warnings.description: People with severe liver disease should not take Suboxone. If you have moderate liver disease, your doctor may want to regularly check your liver function while taking Suboxone.
risk_factors: Taking Suboxone with other drugs that cause liver damage

description_processed.orig: People with severe liver disease should not take Suboxone. If you have moderate liver disease, your doctor may want to regularly check your liver function while taking Suboxone.

risks_warnings.title: Severe allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Suboxone can cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). This is a medical emergency and you get medical attention immediately.

description_processed.orig: Suboxone can cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). This is a medical emergency and you get medical attention immediately.

risks_warnings.title: Death from lack of oxygen to the body (respiratory depression)
risks_warnings.description: Suboxone can cause respiratory depression, coma and death when mixed with alcohol or other drugs that slow the nervous system. Most reports are with people who abused Suboxone with other medications by self-injecting without their doctor knowing. People with lung problems should let their doctor know before taking Suboxone.
risk_factors: Taking with alcohol or other drugs that slow the nervous system

description_processed.orig: Suboxone can cause respiratory depression, coma and death when mixed with alcohol or other drugs that slow the nervous system. Most reports are with people who abused Suboxone with other medications by self-injecting without their doctor knowing. People with lung problems should let their doctor know before taking Suboxone.

risks_warnings.title: Dosing between products
risks_warnings.description: There are differences between the sizes and strengths of Suboxone film. Changing the size or strength of a film can affect the amount of drug absorbed into the body causing under or over-dosing. Be careful.

description_processed.orig: There are differences between the sizes and strengths of Suboxone film. Changing the size or strength of a film can affect the amount of drug absorbed into the body causing under or over-dosing. Be careful.

risks_warnings.title: Neonatal withdrawal syndrome
risks_warnings.description: Buprenorphine, one of the medications in Suboxone passes into breast milk. Women with a history of long-term opioid use increase the risk of neonatal withdrawal syndrome. Symptoms include irritability, vomiting, diarrhea, tremor and lack of weight gain. Opioid withdrawal in infants is a life-threatening emergency and needs medical help right away.
risk_factors: Long-term use of opioids in mother

description_processed.orig: Buprenorphine, one of the medications in Suboxone passes into breast milk. Women with a history of long-term opioid use increase the risk of neonatal withdrawal syndrome. Symptoms include irritability, vomiting, diarrhea, tremor and lack of weight gain. Opioid withdrawal in infants is a life-threatening emergency and needs medical help right away.

risks_warnings.title: Drug interactions
risks_warnings.description: Some medicines can affect enzymes that break down Suboxone. Certain drugs to treat infections, HIV, and seizures can change the amount of Suboxone in the body. Tell your doctor about any medications you are taking and if you notice muscle aches, restlessness, anxiety, tearing eyes, runny nose, excessive sweating, yawning or inability to sleep. These may be symptoms of withdrawal.
risk_factors: Taking drugs that slow or stop breakdown the breakdown of Suboxone

description_processed.orig: Some medicines can affect enzymes that break down Suboxone. Certain drugs to treat infections, HIV, and seizures can change the amount of Suboxone in the body. Tell your doctor about any medications you are taking and if you notice muscle aches, restlessness, anxiety, tearing eyes, runny nose, excessive sweating, yawning or inability to sleep. These may be symptoms of withdrawal.

risks_warnings.title: Driving impairment
risks_warnings.description: Suboxone lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.
risk_factors: Taking other medicines that make you less alert
